Posts.Content: I had it as a primary treatment. Very, very slight loose stool after about two weeks. Also after about two weeks it would sting to urinate.....but no big deal. Treatment took about 25 minutes and I would go home to work out and run. Never got tired. Asked the doctor about getting tired once and his reaction was why would you be getting tired? He felt it was more of a mental issue. Within a week and one half of the last treatment all issues were gone. I had it done in 2005.
Posts.Title: Radiation recovery time

Posts.Content: Brad, Not sure if it is a bounce or not. Since you still have a prostate it could be an infection and that could explain the increase in PSA. I had IMRT 10 years ago . My lowest PSA was 0.295 after two years. It then bounced around going as high as 0.47 six months after the 0.295 reading. For the most part my readings have been in the 0.35 range. My radiation doctor first told me that after treatment the PSA would be like a saw blade. It would probably go up and down , up and down……and it has. I can remember him telling me that I had an 88% chance of being under 0.50 mark ten years down the road. I would say relax and see what it is in 6 months
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Bounce

Posts.Content: I have read a couple studies where brachytherapy was used for salvage treatment after failed EBR. I mentioned it to my doctor and he told me he had done it once with his fingures crossed. So much for the saying you can not have radiation for a salvage treatment if you start with radiation. Times and techniques are changing. I do think you need an organ to have brachytherapy however. Just my two cents
Posts.Title: brachytherapy. as a follow up treatment

Posts.Content: I had IMRT almost 9 years ago. The machine was manufactured by Siemens. I had 38 treatments 200 gy a treatment. I was 59 years old ,3+4, T1C, PSA of 3.41 with 3 samples of ten showing cancer. One at 65% and the other two 5% or less. The radiation center was only `12 minutes away and being retired it gave me something to do each day during the winter. Cost back in 2005 was just over 65,000. My insurance picked up most of the cost I paid around 2600 because my treatment went Nov- Jan……two different years. During treatment after about two weeks I experienced a burning feeling when peeing……..no big deal. The feeling left within a week or so of the end of treatment. Never felt any fatigue in fact I was able to continue running on most days if the temperature was about 20. My bowls loosened up a little but no diarrhea . I put lotion on the area they were radiating everyday so no burns either. Now eight plus years down the road the only side effect I have is occasionally I will see a speck of blood on my stool after a bowl movement. This is not to often. I have since had two colonoscopies and doctor said everything was ok blood was of no concern. I have been told that some foods like popcorn do not digest that completely and will scrape the delicate veins on the trip out causing bleeding. All functions work if you know what I mean. My decision to go with external beam radiation was mainly to stay as far away from incontinence. The surgeon told me that with an operation I should expect some degree of incontinence. As little as a drop to possibly not being able to control my flow. I asked him if he had my numbers what treatment would he as a surgeon seek. He only had to think for a moment and replied external beam radiation. His remark was that as a surgeon “I could not walk around and operate if I was dripping .” He gave me the name of a radiation oncologist. One last remark it was a large team effort.

Posts.Title: External beam radiation: side effects, experiences?

Posts.Content: One thing I forgot to mention is it took about a year and a half to reach a bottom PSA reading. When I first met the doctor he told me that the treatment was not for me if I would be worried if I saw the PSA going up and down, up and down. He said it could be like a saw blade. It still moves up and down very, very slightly, but I no longer worry about it. It has stayed in the 0.30 to 0.39 range. I am checked every six months.
Posts.Title: External beam radiation: side effects, experiences?

Posts.Title: External beam radiation: side effects, experiences?

Posts.Content: AsAdvocate, I have to agree with you. I had IMRT 10 years ago and always had cryotherapy as a back up plan. I have a friend whose father had cryo as his primary treatment and is fine. Also lately I had read that they can sometimes retreat with seeds. Google for salvage treatments after IMRT.
Posts.Title: met with radiologist today

Posts.Content: AsAdvocate, I have to agree with you. I had IMRT 10 years ago and always had cryotherapy as a back up plan. I have a friend whose father had cryo as his primary treatment and is fine. Also lately I had read that they can sometimes retreat with seeds. Google for salvage treatments after IMRT.

Posts.Title: met with radiologist today

Posts.Content: Hopper, I had just about your numbers when I was told the bad news I also was 59 years old. I had IMRT which seems to have worked well. Its going on ten years now. No HT was ever memtioned to me. After reading a number of posts and hearing from guys I often wonder if dollars and cents pops in to our doctors head when they mention HT.. What ever treatment you decide on don't ever look back.
Posts.Title: undecided

Posts.Content: I read a recent article trouting the use of measles to fight PC. I like the idea. "A new study appearing in The Prostate has found that certain measles virus vaccine strain derivatives, including a strain known as MV-CEA, may prove to be an effective treatment for patients with advanced prostate cancer. The findings show that this type of treatment, called virotherapy, can effectively infect, replicate in and kill prostate cancer cells." I read some where that the body then fights off the measles and you're off to the races. Neutrondbob , do you know anything about Red Clover. I may be getting this mixed up but I thought I read that it was being used in a phase 2 study. It has strong isoflavones and I think it said that they minic estrogin . I might have miss read the article. Saw the same ingredience in a soy product for woman and I wrote the manufacturer to see if in was safe for men to take. I believe it was called Soy Balance. The company replied" we think so but you had better ask your doctor. " The soy balance is used to treat hot flashes in woman. Glenn
Posts.Title: Drugs used in PCa~warfare~some are new~onco-docs use such

Posts.Content: Not sure about the answer to your question but my oncologist told me that the thinking is that the good ….normal prostate cells although damaged by radiation are able to repair themselves and reproduce while the cancerous cells usually can not repair themselves and eventually die. The radiation damages the DNA and the ability to reproduce.. One thought though is that most guys with prostate cancer are older and thus already have had a family…..just my four cents….
Posts.Title: Radiation treatment and fertility

Posts.Content: OK something to think about. Impotence from an operation is caused because the nerves are cut , removed or damaged severely. It is like cutting the cable to your telephone. If removed or cut , drugs are not going to help you. People will tell you that radiation will not cause immediate impotence. And that is true. If it develops it will occur slowly and down the road a bit. What can happen is that the radiation causes the veins to age faster and thus eventually ED can occurs. Dr. Charles Myers has a video explaining the results from each type of treatment. He states if I remember correctly that about 80% of the men with ED from radiation can be helped by ED pills now available that increase blood flow circulation. You might want to do a google search for Dr. Charles Myers also referred to as Snuffy Myers. He mentioned in his video, to my amazement , that radiation actually has little effect on the nerves. I went the IMRT route almost nine years ago and everything is still working fine. My biggest worries were side affects. I always felt I could live with ED but not being able to control my urine was something I wanted to stay as far away from as possible. Radiation gave me the best chance for urine control.
Posts.Title: new member and trying to decide on surgery vs. radiation

Posts.Content: Hopper, I had just about your numbers when I was told the bad news I also was 59 years old. I had IMRT which seems to have worked well. Its going on ten years now. No HT was ever memtioned to me. After reading a number of posts and hearing from guys I often wonder if dollars and cents pops in to our doctors head when they mention HT.. What ever treatment you decide on don't ever look back.
